text:
PAX: I want to introduce
Trevor more fully. As I said, he's a lecturer
here in the Department of Management Science and
Engineering at Stanford.

And he teaches a graduate
level course titled, entrepreneurial
management finance, which we're going to talk about.

He's also the managing
partner and founder at Flywheel Ventures, and has
over 20 years of experience investing, 20 years of
experience in entrepreneurial

and operating experience
in Technology Ventures. He's also the past director of
the National Venture Capital

Association, co-founder of
the New Mexico Venture Capital Association, helped create the
Rocky Mountain Venture Capital

Association. So a lot of experience there. I also want to add that he is
also a former student of CGOE

as well. So he also did his master's
degree here at Stanford while he was working-- so on
a part time and online basis.

And so we will talk a little
bit about his experience as an online student,
how that's influenced

the way he runs
this class, and why he likes to have professional
students join and be part of it

remotely, and how that's
influenced his professional life beyond his teaching
and his philosophy.

So with that, Trevor, I gave
a high level background. But I think the
place to start maybe

is just hearing more
about what your background

and your professional journey. Maybe we can start as
an engineer, all the way to being a managing partner.

And let's just start there,
hear a little bit more about your background. TREVOR LOY: OK,
well, thanks, Pax.

And it's great to be
here with everyone. I hope wherever you are in
the country or the world that things are going well.

It's certainly a period of
more change and uncertainty than we've seen in a while. And that lends itself to
the startup experience

and what our course
is about, which has a lot to do with managing
all of the various uncertainties

and decisions and dilemmas
that you encounter in building a startup. And obviously, we'll talk more
about that here in a minute.

To answer your
question, Pax, there's one common thread of
three different things

that I do in parallel. The three things
I do in parallel are run a venture capital firm
that I founded 25 years ago

and still invest out
of, building startups, sitting on boards, the
whole soup to nuts gamut.

I also teach, and
I've been teaching this course for
almost 15 years now

and been teaching at Stanford. And I helped build
the entrepreneurship center in the
engineering school, gosh,

more than 25 years ago now. And I also do a lot of
policy work, frankly,

around the globe with
governments and universities and other organizations,
helping to build

entrepreneurial ecosystems. And that's really the
thread that binds all three of those things together.

I'm interested in the
entrepreneurial experience at the actual level
of the startup company

and also at the level of helping
people start venture capital firms to support entrepreneurs,
and then at the level of policy,

helping people build
new emerging startup ecosystems around the world. And that's of been the common
thread for all of my experience,

at least in the
last 20, 25 years. Happy to then back
up, if you'd like,

and talk about how I got there. But anything you want
me to weigh in on first on that high level intro?

PAX: No, that's wonderful. And I do want to circle back
to all three of those things and how that comes back to--

obviously, the teaching
is, as you said, an important part of that. You're both running companies
at the individual level,

helping train or teach
people how to do that through your teaching. But you're also thinking
about the larger ecosystems,

the systems that
enable and empower people to create those kind of
entrepreneurial organizations.

I would love to come-- I do want to come back to them. I want that to be the focus. But I also know that
before you were a venture,

before you founded Flywheel
Ventures, that you would also--

essentially been an engineer,
you had been a manager. Could you talk a little
bit about that experience

and what drove you
to make that switch to being a managing partner? For many of us, we don't
want to make that switch.

So what prompted you to do that? TREVOR LOY: Yeah, well, so
if we go all the way back

to the age of the dinosaurs when
I was an undergraduate student

at Stanford as well,
my undergrad degree was a bachelor's in
electrical engineering with a focus on
semiconductor physics.

And I started my career once
I graduated at Intel back

in, really, the
heyday, back when Intel was like
NVIDIA is today, sort of the dominant chipmaker
growing like a rocket ship

and just trying to keep up. And I did a couple of
things while I was at Intel.

I worked on actual chip
design, contributed to the first
Pentium, and then the

follow on Pentium II
generation of chips. But after a couple of
years of doing that,

it became clear to me-- and I
suppose to some other folks-- that while I was a perfectly
decent engineer and fine

at implementing microprocessor
designs, I had a little bit more

of an interest and a talent
for bringing teams of engineers together and leading them in
the process of shipping products

and getting them out the door. And so that led me to a series
of entrepreneurial experiences.

Three startups in particular,
one in the chip industry, one in the wireless
systems industry, and then

one obligatory.com startup
in the digital music space.

And of those three, I had one
IPO, one M&A, and one failure. And as I sometimes joke, but
it's really true, most of what

I feel like I learned
about entrepreneurship, I learned from the failure. We can talk more about that.

That's a topic we actually talk
about quite a bit in this course that I teach.

Then I actually, as you
mentioned, while I was still working, I started a
dual master's program

in electrical engineering
and the management science and engineering department,
where I now teach.

And I did the
first half of that. So probably two or three
years, I did classes remotely.

I was going to say
online, but this predates the-- the internet
was just in the formation. And so that was back
when you guys would

record lectures and ship
them to me on a VHS tape, and then I would
complete the homework

and I would fax it
back to my professors. So we've come a long way in our
ability to interact in real time

since then. But that really does lay the
groundwork for my interest in involving students,
who are still working

and who can
participate remotely. And I know we'll
talk more about that and how that is implemented in
our course here in a minute.

When I came back then to do the
second half of those two degrees

on campus, that's when
I had the opportunity to work with a professor
named Tom Byers

and build something called the
Stanford Technology Ventures program, which is
the entrepreneurship

center in Stanford's
School of Engineering and somewhat controversial
idea back in those days

that we should be teaching
entrepreneurial management and finance and all
kinds of startup

stuff to technical
students and not only to the business students. Obviously, in the
25, 30 years since we

started that, the
wisdom of doing that has been validated
many times over, not just at Stanford, but
now around the world at lots

of universities. And as a technical
person myself who then entered the
entrepreneurial world,

I just believe very
strongly that exposing entrepreneurial thinking
and principles to people

with technical
backgrounds just has a wonderful impact, both
individually on those people, but also collectively on the
kinds of products and solutions

that get brought into
the world as a result. PAX: I think that's fantastic.

I want to maybe dive in a little
bit more on two of those things. Which is the first, I do want
to talk about the failure

and how much you
learned from that. And this is a thing-- I've had a couple of
these conversations recently in similar sessions
and this idea of learning

from your failures
and not just what you did wrong, but from what I
understand, the emotion of it.

I mean, it's incredibly
emotionally draining to go through
something like that. And it's an important lesson for
anybody and for entrepreneurs.

So let's start there. And then I do want to come
back to this idea of why it's important to teach technical
students a little bit

about the
entrepreneurial mindset. So maybe start with
this idea of the failure and why you learn
so much from it.

And we can already begin
talking about the class, how you think about that, and
integrate it into the class as well.

TREVOR LOY: OK, sure, yeah. The entrepreneurial journey--
and when I say that,

let me just clarify and
we'll come back to this also, I'm sure-- we're not just talking
about starting companies.

I believe entrepreneurship
is much broader than starting businesses.

It's a form, really,
of leadership. It's a leadership style that
starts with opportunity first,

instead of resource constraints,
and assumes that, first, you figure out what the right
opportunity is to pursue,

and then you'll be
able to go assemble the team and the financing
that you need to actually

go execute on that plan. And our course is really
about the back half of that.

It's how do you pull
together the team? And how do you pull
together the financing? And what's the
interaction of those two?

So on the failure standpoint,
one of my observations is, again, whether
you're in a startup

company, or some other form of
entrepreneurial organization, or even in a big
company or government,

entrepreneurial
leadership is really about this opportunity-focused
way of leading first.

And that requires
a tremendous amount of uncertainty, a tremendous
amount of iteration.

Because by definition,
you have this sense of what the
opportunity is, but you don't know what the
solution is going to be.

And nonetheless, you
start out anyway. The cliche is you
build the plane

while you're already on the
runway or even in the air. And what people sometimes
don't talk enough about--

lots of accelerators and
courses and speakers and you can get on podcasts and
universities and whatnot,

they talk about a lot of the
tactical aspects of that. What I find still doesn't
get talked about enough

is the actual human experience,
the psychological and emotional journey that, that involves and
the stress that you're under,

particularly, amidst
all that uncertainty and your responsibility for the
team that you've put together

and your responsibility for
making sure that there's money in the bank to pay them.

And one of the
reasons why I believe failure is such a great teacher
is when things don't work

and you've been
under that stress, it actually opens you up a
little bit more as a human being

to really think hard about what
led you to things not working, et cetera.

When you go down an
entrepreneurial path and everything kind of really
more or less works out well,

there tends to be a
revisionist history in that you forget that you
had all that suffering and pain

and that you made a bunch
of mistakes along the way. And it's just how
we're wired as humans. I'm not a psychologist,
but my experience

is it's really easy to just
adopt a persona of someone who's become successful.

And actually, you lose
access to all that knowledge that you gained and
was available to you. But when you fail,
you can't escape that.

And so it forces you to embrace
everything that you learned. And that actually makes you
a stronger human but also

a stronger leader
and, in my opinion, a better entrepreneur,
eventually. And that's why so many
successful entrepreneurs

you hear from talk about
some experience of failure they had along the way towards
eventually reaching success

and how pivotal that
failure stage was for them. PAX: That's great. So I mean to say
back what I'm hearing

is a sense that failure
teaches you humility, and humility teaches
you self-reflection, and that allows you to become
a better leader, a better

entrepreneur, a better
business person. TREVOR LOY: That's right. I think it's reflection
and absorption.

PAX: Reflection, OK. TREVOR LOY: When
you're successful, it's really easy to
just dismiss the lessons

that you should be
learning because you assume that everything
you did worked out. And failure faces you
straight in the eye

and doesn't let you avoid it. And that's valuable. PAX: And is that something--
obviously in a class--

I don't know if you
simulate failure, but I'm assuming,
even if you did, it won't have that kind
of emotional resonance

that you would have, having
worked on something over years. But how do you
introduce that when you're teaching
entrepreneurs, or even when

you're thinking about policy? I mean, that's probably a very-- you probably want to encourage
a policy or an ecosystem that

allows people to take
risks, allows and expects failure, a certain
amount of failure. Because if you
don't have failure,

maybe you're not trying
big enough ideas. But does so in a way that
maybe provides a safety net or some resilience
within the system.

So can you talk about how
that works into both that kind of classroom and maybe--

or coaching experience, as
well as that policy piece that you work on? TREVOR LOY: Yeah, I'll take
those in reverse order.

I think on the policy front,
that is the hardest place. The incentive structure in
most policymaking environments

is set up to punish
failure quite aggressively and actually not to reward
success all that much.

Especially, at least, in the US
and other similar policymaking

environments, the people making
the policy decisions almost never have a longevity
of their position

that they're in,
where they'll still be around by the time the
outcome becomes clearer either way.

And as a result, they're
very sensitive to what it looks like is happening
in the first year or two.

Whereas, we know the average
company from seed financing to a successful exit for
companies that succeed

is about nine years now. Which, by the way, is
more than double what it was when I started my career.

And if you look at ecosystems,
an ecosystem emerging

is at least generational and
often two generations before you really get critical mass.

And so it takes a rare kind of
person involved in the policy front, who has that kind of
long term commitment and who,

frankly, has some source
of financing, or power, or influence, where they can
stick around and help shepherd

for two decades or more. And that's one of the biggest
challenges in that environment. For the class, one of
the things we try to do,

our class is very experiential. There's obviously the
traditional readings and videos and things we ask
people to read before class.

Every week, we have
a case study that is the primary form in
which we teach the class

and experience it. And in addition,
most weeks, we have some form of
interactive exercise

inside the class as well. Each class is three hours long. So we have plenty of real estate
to both have the case discussion

and then do some
kind of role play. And the reason why we do so
much in this experiential way

is we are trying to
expose our students to all these different common
dilemmas that they're

going to face in the
entrepreneurial journey, whether that's
from the beginning, picking co-founders
and deciding how you're

going to divide the initial
equity to how to negotiate with your first employees,
how to negotiate financing

with angels or VCs, all
the way until figuring out, maybe when it's time for you as
a founder, who's been the CEO

to step aside and
bring in somebody new, and how to see that as
growth and opportunity

and not as a failure. And we try to create
all of these role plays so that the
students can experience

at least a tiny little bit
of what it actually feels like to be in that situation. We have mock board meetings.

We have mock negotiations
over term sheets. And we will teach
and students will

learn specific parts
of a term sheet and how to model a
cap table and how

to think about unit economics
and their business model. But ultimately, the real goal
at the higher level of the class

is for students to remember
what it felt like for a moment to be trying to figure out
how to do that negotiation.

So that they can draw
on that expertise. And it's just slightly
less of a mystery when they encounter
it in real life.

PAX: That makes a lot of sense. So it's just the experiential
part, the role playing, is a crucial piece of just
simulating and getting students

to experience that, as you
said, emotionally, understanding that emotional valence. Obviously, different in a
class than when you're doing it

as an entrepreneur, but it's
important to have that exposure. TREVOR LOY: Well,
and it's precisely that you can fail at that
exercise in our class

and there's really
no downside to it. I should note that
we almost never

grade those exercises
to the extent that they're grading or
homework-assigned related

to those. We tend to assign a
reflection exercise, where

the deliverable is what you
learned from doing the role play, whether it worked or not,
whether you can negotiate a deal

or not, whether you and
your mock co-founders could come to an agreement or
not, whether in a board meeting,

the CEO was fired
by the board or not, all these kinds of things. We ask you to then reflect
on what you learned

and what you do differently and
how you'd advise somebody else going through that. And then the only part that's
graded is that reflection.

So it creates an
environment, where you can experiment with
taking different positions. You can negotiate
really aggressively.

You can try to be a team builder
and build collaboration first. And there are different
ways to do it.

And we like to let students
explore different approaches. And again, the stakes in the
course are next to nonexistent.

So rather see you fail now and
learn from that a little bit and then move forward and
implement that in your life.

PAX: That's really interesting. And just one thing
that I think of is just whenever you're in
those experiences and outside

of a simulation, you
tend to fall back on what you're most
comfortable with. And you don't have
that-- you don't

feel comfortable to take the
risk to experiment with, say, a more aggressive approach
if you're more conciliatory, or if you tend to be aggressive,
trying to do the consensus

building. And what sounds
really interesting is allow people to not
just play different roles, but explore different
personalities

and how you approach
those different problems. I could see that as being
really, really valuable

as a learning experience to
individuals and students, so yeah. TREVOR LOY: Well,
the other piece

that I think comes
into play with that, that sort of accompanies that,
we do tease the basic concepts

and structures. So you'll build cap
tables for companies. You'll fill out term sheets.

You'll model the impact of
different terms in a term sheet on what's called the waterfall.

Which is calculations of
what the actual payout to different employees, or
founders, or investors will

be based on how you negotiate
a term sheet, et cetera. And again, 10 years
later, you may not

remember exactly what
the difference was between a participating
liquidation preference and non-participating.

But what I hope you'll
remember is the principle that was at stake, the idea that
if you don't pay attention

to some of these details,
you can find that-- you assumed that
the payout would

be a function of who owned
what percentage of the company. And in reality, investors have
lots of little creative ways

to change so that they get
paid out more than what you would think that they would. And if you don't know
about that and you

don't have good advisors
to remind you of that, it can sneak up on you.

So ultimately, the
more quantitative part of the course, there is
some spreadsheet work

and some calculations of
various things or whatnot. And that's really
aimed at demystifying all of these concepts.

And no one of them are
actually rocket science. We're not doing linear
algebra or machine learning.

We're just using Excel
and doing basic math. But most of the time, the
terminology that the venture

industry throws around,
like any profession, there's often more complexity
with the terminology

than actually needs
to be the case. And that's in part
probably purposeful because it makes entrepreneurs
feel a little bit more

on the back of their heels. It's more complicated
than it actually is. And so the other
goal of our class

is you come out of it having
demystified all these things that you thought
were complicated. And now, you've done
them and you realize

they're not complicated. Maybe the human
negotiation part is. But the actual
underlying concepts

are pretty straightforward. And hopefully, then
when you go forward, you're not intimidated
by that part of it,

whether you're at a startup,
or on the investment side, or anything else. PAX: That's great.

And maybe one other
thing that you're saying there, as you mentioned,
these company can go-- it's nine

years-- from seed to exit. And you compress that. So you can see in the
short period of time,

this is what you negotiated. This is what it will
be nine years later. And so it allows you to see
that feedback loop, which is--

a nine year feedback
loop is not one that's easy to learn
from necessarily, and so. TREVOR LOY: Yeah, 9
years in 10 weeks,

so it's about a week, a year-- a year, a week. The other thing I'd mention
about the class, Pax,

is almost every week,
we have a guest speaker who joins and really
leads a major part,

if not most of the discussion. And all of our guest speakers
are both highly successful,

experienced professionals. Some of them are
startup founders. Our first week, it's Josh
Reeves, who's the founder of

and still runs-- he's the CEO of
Gusto, which is a $10 million, what we call a decacorn now.

And this is a Stanford
engineering graduate himself. Then we have top tier
venture capital investors.

We also have experienced Silicon
Valley lawyers, particularly for the term sheet stuff.

And they help
advise the students on how that works in the
real world, et cetera.

So there's a heavy piece of
practitioner's involvement. But I would also emphasize,
while all of these people

are big names in
their fields, they're chosen because they're
great teachers.

The focus of this course is on
the students and the experience that the students are having.

And my job as the instructor,
working with the guests each week is to
curate an experience

that the students will go
through so that they encounter these dilemmas and
these decisions

and these feelings and
these terms on their own, again, about a year, a week.

So that when they
come through it, they've at least
touched the surface of what it felt like
to be in that position.

PAX: That's great. I want to maybe take a
step back from the class itself and come
back to something

you said earlier, which
is related to the class. Which is this idea
of, back when you

started both the technology-- I think the
entrepreneurship program within the School of
Engineering and this class,

that it was unusual to want
to take the kind of business mindset and teach it
to technical students,

to engineers. I'm curious, if you
want to expand on that, but other things that
you have been seeing that

have changed across the
ecosystem in those 20, 25 years that you've
been teaching,

that you've been practicing
as a managing partner? So let's start there. And then there are
a few that I know

you've worked on that I would
love to bring up as well if they don't come up initially. TREVOR LOY: OK. Yeah, so at the time, when Tom
and I were first rolling out

this program, the general
view across universities was that entrepreneurship
was a skill that

was appropriate as part
of a business school MBA type curriculum, in the same
way that you might specialize

in an MBA in
accounting, and you'd learn the whole skill
set around accounting.

And our view was
quite different, which is that entrepreneurship
is less a skill

and it's much more a mindset. And so although there
are practical examples

that I was just giving
examples of in the class of specific, very
tactical situations

that you encounter in building
a high growth startup,

we don't necessarily view that
as the only expression that's relevant.

And again, we believe that
entrepreneurship is a 21st century leadership style that's
appropriate across all kinds

of domains, whether it's
business, or nonprofits, or government.

There's even a
former student who's now a priest, who
tells me about how he uses his entrepreneurial
thinking to change

some things about how
he goes about delivering faith-based teaching.

So there are all kinds of
domains in which this stuff can come into play. And so with that spin
on it, our feeling

is, what we're trying to do is
expose people to this leadership mindset and then
have them apply that

to some skill-based area that
happens to be their specialty. That could be a
chemical engineering.

That could be a
mechanical engineer. It could be machine learning. It could be-- we sometimes
have medical students or law

students. We actually believe
that when you have a core expertise, that's
about what you know how to do,

then you apply this leadership
mentality on top of that, it creates what we call
t-shaped people, where

the vertical part of the
T is this deep expertise and the broad top of the T
is this leadership mindset.

That is what we
really try to teach throughout all the courses
in the engineering school

at Stanford. So that's where we started. And then your question about,
what's changed over those years?

There are two things. One is within universities
in particular and education more broadly, the idea now that
people with deeper expertise

should be exposed to
entrepreneurship as a leadership approach has gained a lot more.

That's widely accepted now,
not every single place, but mostly across kind of top
tier research universities

at least. And what's really exciting is
we have seen it now move outside of just technical students.

And there are arts schools now
that teach entrepreneurship. Because if you think
about it, artists

are actually more likely
to become entrepreneurs than engineers because
there's no big Google company

you work for if
you're an artist. But artists are much
more likely to have to build a career on their own. And so it's been really exciting
to see entrepreneurship spread

in all kinds of
different disciplines. The other biggest
change I've seen, which is more in the real world,
is a shift in the power dynamic.

When I started both building
the program at Stanford and then after that, when I started
my venture capital firm,

the power dynamic was
very tilted in favor of venture capitalists and
angel investors, the people

with the money. And that was partly
because there was a scarcer pool of capital
to fund early stage ventures.

But a lot of it was
the lack of access to information
for entrepreneurs.

There wasn't social media. There wasn't yet blogging
by VCs or founders.

There certainly weren't things
like Y Combinator, Techstars, or other programs. So there was almost
no way for a founder

to learn about how all this
worked, unless they just happened to have another founder
that they were friends with, who

had already been through it. It was very much an
apprenticeship type approach. And that let a lot of
investors, unfortunately,

take advantage of entrepreneurs. And the best thing that's
happened in the last 20, 25 years is almost a
complete inversion

of that dynamic, at least in any
established startup ecosystem, where it's understood now that
the truly scarce resource are

talented founders
and the opportunities that they're passionate
about solving. And the capital is more
like, not quite a commodity,

because I think there are
certain things that investors still bring to the table, but
it's the view of professional

and, I think, successful
investors today is and should be much more that
we are just service providers

and we happen to supply
capital in the same way that a lawyer provides
you with legal advice, or your audit firm does
your audit in your books.

And that shift in
the power dynamic is another thing that we
look at a lot in the course. Because, again, our course looks
at both the financial incentives

that are created
by how you finance a business and the implications
of that on the management culture you're trying to build.

And those two things have a
sort of codependent effect

on each other. And well, we can
talk more about that. But I'll stop there for now.

PAX: Yeah, that's
really interesting. And I wonder if you could
talk maybe if you've seen another shift in--

I don't know power dynamic
is the right word-- but I'll just say the
geographic distribution

and how you're seeing
companies develop? I know that's something
you've worked on. Although you spend a lot of
time here in the Bay Area

and at Stanford, you're also
traveling around the globe, as you said, trying to
do this policy work, build other ecosystems.

And that's something
you've been working on long before the pandemic
shifted this huge shift to work

from home and changes
and just where people are living and working. So I'd love to hear you say a
few words about what you were

seeing back then, which was
only like six, seven years ago,

or maybe longer ago,
and then if you've seen that play out a little bit
or accelerated in recent years.

TREVOR LOY: Yeah, it starts
with the observation. And these are not
my original words,

but I honestly can't remember
where I first heard this. But the observation
that talent is equally

distributed geographically,
but opportunity is not. There are smart people and great
universities all over the world.

And there are smart
founders coming out of those universities,
either right after school, or more
commonly, actually,

after they've been in industry
working for 5 or 10 years. Which is why we think
it's so appropriate to involve professional
students in the class.

And yet, historically,
the capital was very centralized
in Silicon Valley

and just a handful
of other places, really, around the world. And what's changed? Obviously, Silicon Valley is
still the dominant location.

And it has continued to grow. So the amount of investment
that happens in Silicon Valley has continued to grow
quite nicely in that time.

But in parallel,
there are just a lot more places around
the globe now, where there is a functioning,
successful startup ecosystem,

whether that's places in Europe,
or Southeast Asia, or China, and then increasingly

which is where

to build companies
to solve problems based on the knowledge

there's this debate that

And I don't find
that conversation very revealing or helpful.

My experience starting
about 15 years ago, at least, maybe even
a little longer,

is that most companies,
certainly once they get beyond the first
8 or 10 people,

almost every single company has
people that are geographically distributed. And that's just because the
scarcest resource is talent.

And so if you're going
after an opportunity and you're trying to be first
to solve the problem that's

associated with
that opportunity, you need the best talent. And you need to be able to
find and use that talent

wherever it is. And because the talent comes
in the form, at least for now, of human beings and not
AI-based humanoid robots,

there are certain
things that you're just constrained by because humans
have significant others and they have children, or they
have parents who need care,

or they have life
situations, where they need to be in
the geographic area where they're at.

And so pretty much
every company I've invested in for
the last 15 years has had employees, at least,
in multiple locations.

A handful of them
have been truly fully distributed, where no one
person is in the same place.

But I think that got
a little oversold. I think most companies
have pockets of people

in different geographies. And then those
pockets of people need to work with other
pockets of people.

And so to your point that you
heard from someone else, which I completely agree is
spot on, what it really

speaks to is being
thoughtful about leadership and about process. And my observation is that
even though companies--

the companies that have tried
to remain where everyone is in the same building,
if you don't still

put in the same amount
of thoughtfulness into your leadership approach
and the culture you're building

and the processes-- and this is something we
talk about in week one of the class with Josh Reeves.

He talks about all
of the leadership processes he's had
to build and change, since it was just him
and his two co-founders.

And now, they have,
I forget, many tens of thousands of employees. They actually have three
corporate headquarters,

all of which are co-equal. And that's a very
deliberate choice

on his part to structure
the company in that way. And he talks about why. And at the end of
the day, it is true

that for certain
kinds of activities, humans are better
at doing things if we're all in the same room.

But if you just rely on that
to happen without putting any process or
leadership into it,

I often find that whatever
advantages would be there from people, being in
the same place actually

are lost because people just
assume that it's organically going to happen
just because they happen to be in the same room.

And so having, from
a very early stage, to manage an organization
that at least has

some portion of
the workforce not in the same physical location
often forces the leadership

to be more thoughtful
about how the company is going to do things. And that often leads to
a more successful company

than it would have
been because they had to put those
processes in place anyway and they actually were forced
to put them in place sooner.

It's a little bit-- there's
an analog I talk about with companies, startups
from emerging markets.

Classic example is the
Israeli startup community, which is successful,
precisely in my view,

because it's such
a small market. There is no startup
in Israel that imagines that its whole
big eventual goal is to get

80% market share in Israel. That would still
be a tiny business. And so if you start
a company in Israel,

you assume that you've
got to figure out global markets from the
second week of the company. And as a result, those
companies are very

good at competing globally. Whereas, you see startups
in much bigger markets--

like, for example, not to pick
out anything in particular, but just to
illustrate the point,

I see a lot of German startups,
where the founders are focused on just building a company
that has a really large market

share in Germany. And that country's
economy is large enough that you can build a
mid-sized company doing that.

And that's why Germany has so
many great mid-sized companies. But if you're trying to
truly build a world class

international company, that
assumption that you don't need to do that for the first 5
or 10 years-- because, first,

you're just going to focus
on your domestic market-- actually prevents you from
ever building the skill

set or the processes you
need to be a global company. So there's the team pace but
also the market focus piece.

hand-in-hand in my view. PAX: That's really interesting.

And then we do a week

So you're exiting. And then actually, the very

which is a really unique,
very interactive discussion. There are no right answers. But where we
present the students

with 5 to 15 tricky, thorny
ethical dilemmas and have them

talk about. First, they vote
anonymously on what they do. Then they talk about why
they chose what they did.

And the really fascinating piece
is that you almost always find that students split about--

between three
choices, the way you could deal with the
situation, they're roughly split about a third each.

And it's often quite
shocking for people, who assumed that the answer that
they chose was the obvious right

ethical answer for them to
discover that 2/3 of their peers don't agree with that.

And that leads to a
really kind of way to bring all the different
pieces of the class together on that last day.
